Some of the big interconnector projects will be in place by 2030. The problem will be bridging the gap to there.

There is some low-hanging fruit here. Decarbonisation is coming in by 2030 and, as the Deputy is aware, all State assets have to meet an A3 level of energy by then. However, it is probably within the grasp of the committee that if the 2030 date was extended out, major energy users such as hospitals on the east coast would not transfer from oil to electricity in that period and therefore the capacity of the grid would be preserved for other uses such as residential, commercial or industrial. It is only a simple thing to push out the 2030 deadline.

My final question relates to modern methods of construction. We have a very good facility in Offaly. Dominic will be very familiar with it. The Laois & Offaly Education and Training Board has been investing heavily in it. Where does he see us in terms of the European standard or pace in the delivery and roll-out of housing?

I will respond very briefly and my colleagues might come in. On modern methods of construction, any builder building a house will choose the most efficient certified product that is available. Modern methods of construction are being used widely from the timber-frame ICF system to light-gauge steel. A construction site now is completely different. When a house is being constructed using the most modern timber frame or whatever it is in 24 weeks or 26 weeks, the construction is not the problem in terms of a blockage; it is everything else before that, which is measured in years.

Yes, absolutely. The future is already here. Many of the people in this room and many builders are already adopting modern methods of construction. Mount Lucas is a brilliant facility. The MMC demonstration park should be open later this year. That will be a showhouse for all the new techniques and technologies that are being developed. We have an industry that is ready to roll them out as soon as they become available. Issues around NSAI and agrément certification are holding up certain technologies and methods but, by and large, we are very active in this space. I think we compare pretty well internationally also.

Apartments are using the same precast pods and so on. The key to modern methods of construction is the pipeline. No factory is going to set up and employ 500 people and then after a year or two the numbers fall off a cliff and that is it. The pipeline will determine the extent to which we use modern methods of construction.
Regardless of the method of construction, we need infrastructure.

I must speak in the Seanad in 20 minutes so I will ask my questions and I will look back at the answers if that is okay. I know that is not the best way of doing it. I apologise for missing some of the context as I had another event to attend. Some of my questions might be a bit duplicative.

Could we touch a little bit on judicial review? I know there has been lots of narrative about judicial review being a big challenge for the delivery of infrastructure and housing in general. What is the perspective of the witnesses on that and do they see it as being a big issue?

When this came up earlier, we outlined that the rate of judicial review in Ireland is 26 per million of population whereas in the UK, the other common law jurisdiction that has judicial reviews, it is running at less than five per million of population. We would argue - we have been quoted in the newspapers as saying this - that it is out of control. We believe it is. The system of judicial review in Ireland means that anyone at any stage of the process can take a judicial review and object, which is unique also in terms of our comparison with other jurisdictions in regard to legal costs as well. We are the only country that I am aware of – I might be incorrect – where the cost, irrespective of whether you win, is paid for by the State.
That is providing the judicial review is made on environmental grounds.
Glenveagh currently has three judicial reviews in process. How does that relate to its stance on judicial review being a block to infrastructure and housing?

Yes, there are exceptions. Judicial review is unfortunately being widely used in many different circumstances at the moment. I would argue that the rate of judicial review by builders is minuscule in comparison to some others.

But increasing. We are seeing an increase in developers taking judicial reviews. It is important to have that on the record. From my perspective, the issue around judicial review is not so much having the access to justice, because we know that the threshold for taking a judicial review is quite high. I cannot turn around and say I am not happy with that. There has to be evidence and all of these things.
I fundamentally disagree with a statement saying that the threshold for judicial review in Ireland is very high.
Okay. I disagree with Mr. O'Connell's perspective on that as well. There are challenges to the planning decisions which are leading to judicial reviews being able to be taken.

Yes, we went through this earlier. An awful lot of the judicial reviews that are successful are based on administrative and minor technical grounds. That is just a fact. They are not based on substantive issues.
Yes, I suppose that is the point; they are being taken because there was a procedural issue at the planning level.

For some housing projects in Ireland recently - we have a paper-based system – you would literally have to bring a van load of documents into the planning office. If a page is missing or there are errors in the administrative function surrounding the paperwork, the planning permission falls. Planning permissions are falling in these circumstances even though the local authority has zoned the land for development purposes.

I think we are actually in agreement about the issue with the planning system. It is allowing the door to be open to judicial review in some instances, as opposed to legitimate judicial review and citizen accountability being a legitimate mechanism for access to justice, as outlined in the Aarhus Convention.

No, it is the legal cost structure as well. There is no punitive element at all for what we and some of our members have experienced. The Irish Times put it very well in one of its editorials around this process. It said it is a cash cow for the legal profession.

That is interesting, because the punitive element would be based on the fact that there is such a high bar. If I was an individual taking a review I would need to have a big lump sum to be able to access the lawyers. The punitive element is on the person choosing to take the review. They are obviously taking it for reasons they believe in or they have the grounds on which to take it. We might disagree, but we might have a different ideology behind that perspective.
Probably, yes.

That is really interesting because if we are identifying the same issue in the system from different perspectives, which I think we are, that points to the challenges around planning and how decisions are being made. Mr. O'Connell spoke about the paper-based system, which is obviously archaic, and how challenging that is. That is really interesting from my perspective.

In the opening statement there was a reference to funding and viability. Do the witnesses see the funding and viability of development as an ongoing challenge or has that been solved with the VAT reduction and the croí cónaithe cities grant of €60,000 per apartment that developers can use for the building of apartments?

Viability is always an issue from a regional perspective. There is a cloud hanging over every single development until certainty is brought to the business case. A developer will always have certainty in relation to costs to some degree with what happens inside his own boundary, but he has no control whatsoever over what happens outside his boundary, especially for services. The cost of delivering those services either makes that site viable or unviable.
When it comes to the question of viability, what kind of profits were drawn down by investors last year in 2024?

The way the cost structure works in the construction industry means that builders have very little control over the vast majority of costs. In a typical scenario, any builder or developer has to go and seek finance because of the risky nature of any development - the length of time it takes to get through the planning system in Ireland, the judicial review process and to get a utility connection. The vast majority of investors who fund a construction project look for a margin of between 10% and 15% for a development.
So there is a 10% to 15% profit for development. Are developers making a profit on the developments they are doing?
Absolutely. If you cannot illustrate a profit, you will not get funding.

My question is this: if a profit is being made, then where is the viability gap in terms of the cost? The witnesses are requesting more funding. It is €120,000 per apartment for the cities scheme and then savings are being made of an estimated €60,000 because of the reduction in apartment sizes. Then there is the VAT measure. I think it is something like €200,000 per apartment that developers are saving, compared to prior to the initiatives. Is that now affordable? Is that the end of the subsidies needed for development to take place or is more money still required?

Thankfully, a number of initiatives have come into play in recent months, including the revised apartment design standards, changes to rent pressure zones to attract international finance again and the reduced VAT rate for apartment viability. There has been a lot of talk about the viability gap and it has been publicly stated by the Department of housing and others that there is a viability gap for apartments of about €100,000. We believe those combined measures will fill the gap. However, the initial beneficiary of many changes will be the State because the State is the one purchasing apartments at the moment. It will be purchasing them cheaper.

I am personally familiar with a case where the HSE wants to build a significant extension to a hospital. A person objected to it, as is their right. The council granted it. It went to An Bord Pleanála. An Bord Pleanála granted it. They have done a judicial review solely on the fact they believe the colour of the paint on the exterior wall is not in keeping with the character of the streetscape. That is simple fact.

It was really interesting when we had a councillor group up from Kildare. They met Simon Harris to discuss issues. There were also councillors from Westmeath and Longford. The difference between the councillor groups was stunning. As I was a councillor only a year ago, in many ways I also am speaking as one of them.. The experience was there were lots of houses being built in County Kildare. I would nearly trip up over a new housing estate if I walked out my door in Leixlip. Some people might think that is strange but that is the reality. If I walk around Leixlip, Hereford Park is being built. If I walk over to Celbridge, I can see all around where there is building. If I walk over to Maynooth, there is tonnes. Clane, Naas, you name it but the lads in Longford had nothing. They said the only houses that could be built there were social houses. Is that the reality ye are seeing? I do not mean "ye", but I am just saying all across the board.

I will come in from a regional perspective and then let my colleagues come in. At our national meetings when we have round-table discussions, it would not be unusual to state that west of the Shannon, the majority of houses currently being built are social houses.

Is it a simple metric? The cost of building a three- or four-bedroom house might be €380,000. The cost in north Kildare and Longford is the same, yet you can get €550,000 for it in Leixlip but only €395,000 in Longford. Is it that simple?
There is not huge variation in the cost of construction. The variation is in the cost of land.
The sale price is the big variation between the two and that determines the economics.
And the land comes in then, yes.
In a lot of cases, the difference in the land is not huge.
We can sometimes get a bit lost on the zoned-rezoned value but if you start dividing it out by the number of houses being built on it, it makes sense quick enough.

If you go to places like Prosperous, Allenwood and Monasterevin, councillors want more houses and say they would love to have more housing estates to build up the areas. There is not a decline in population but there is slower growth than there could be. Local people cannot get houses there. They cannot get one-off houses there because we do not want one-off houses in Kildare, judging by the local area plan. Judging by that plan, we are trying to reduce those and put them in towns and villages. All the growth is going into Naas - 50,000 is the plan; Maynooth - 50,000 is the plan; and Leixlip-Celbridge. How do we get Rathcoffey, Prosperous and Allenwood to grow? What can we do there? I am using those as examples. You can swap them out for Meath or Wicklow.
In a lot of the areas the Deputy mentioned, the infrastructure is not there to support-----
Is that Uisce Éireann?
It could be roads or Uisce Éireann. It could be-----

As Mr. Prenty knows, were you to throw 150 houses up in Rathcoffey, the roads would be fine. It would be up by the GAA club. The GAA club is amazing. It looks great. There is a primary school there that would only love to have new kids.
I have not looked at Prosperous but if the land was zoned and serviced then-----
Is it the service issue? Is it the fact it is not serviced from a Uisce Éireann perspective?

It is probably both. We do not have the zoning map right in front of us showing the number of units you could physically build on zoned land. The next issue is servicing. From a water, wastewater and, potentially, an energy perspective, there may be difficulties there as to why the land is not zoned. It may be the case that the local authority is taking a view that it does not want to zone land there.

I would get past that point on not wanting to zone land, because that is ultimately a different type of decision, or it is not possible. I am curious about where it is not possible to go there. Theoretically we could put infrastructure in place to allow that but it might not be financially viable for Uisce Éireann. There might be an element of that.
I do not know the reason for that.
If it was zoned, I am sure Mr. Kennedy and I would be chasing out there-----

That is true, too. There is one other point. This is where I am being slightly parochial. It is not about the witnesses. I feel they have good relations with the local authorities in north Kildare but we have probably been behind on infrastructure delivery. You look at Celbridge; there is only one bridge in Celbridge. You look at Maynooth; there is a relief road there looking to be built for the last ten or 15 years. The witnesses are probably crying their eyes out about why it has not been built, I am sure. They would only love that the light rail would go to Kilcock in the morning. That would solve all these problems for the witnesses so I am preaching to the converted in that sense.

We as an infrastructure committee need to deliver those projects for the witnesses to be able to deliver houses. There are 2,000 houses waiting the other side of Celbridge to be built, in Simmonstown. I was councillor of the local area. I know there is another 1,500 at the back of me in Leixlip.
The bridge is the stumbling block.

The bridge is the issue there. They are living examples. Between them, the witnesses could deliver 4,000 houses with a couple of infrastructural projects but as a State we do not seem to be able to do that any more. That is the single biggest issue. In recent years we have shown we have not been able to deliver those.
You know where we are. An investment of €40-odd million to get the thing going could open up 2,000 homes.

More importantly, I am always conscious that it is not just about delivery of houses but delivery of communities. That is not the witnesses' job. They pay their development contributions and levies but we do not necessarily see that investment being put back into those areas by Kildare County Council. We have not seen capital investment in communities by councils. That is a big issue. New estates are going in but we do not see any new swimming pools in north Kildare. In Leixlip, Celbridge and Maynooth, there are 53,000 people. There is not one swimming pool between them. There is not one proper community centre between them. There is a huge deficit. Okay, there are some sports facilities. We can talk about bridges and roads all we want but we cannot even provide basic social infrastructure for the people. That is where the local authorities need to step up. The witnesses will build houses and pay levies but the local authorities need to step up and deliver for those communities. As a Government, we need to start delivering the infrastructure that allows them to build. In fairness, we have failed to do that in recent years on those basic sites.
There are some places that have soft infrastructure but not the zoned land on which to build additional houses.
Give me an example.
Many county towns west of Kildare have the soft infrastructure already there.
The likes of Nenagh or Clonmel or something.
Nenagh, Tullamore, Portlaoise, Mullingar, etc., but they do not have the required zoned land to build additional houses.
Is it that they do not have the required zoned land or it is not financially viable, in my Longford example?
In those towns mentioned, it would be viable-----
It would be financially viable but there is not the zoned land at this stage.
Correct.
In this day and age.
Yes.
Does Mr. Doheny see that issue in Kildare?
The witnesses can come down to Kildare all they want but I am just saying there is-----
Here are the experts on Kildare.
What is Deputy Neville's question?

My question relates to all the soft infrastructure that is in place in those locations. We are backed up against the wall a little in Kildare in this regard. In fairness, as was stated, the soft infrastructure is there in places like Tullamore, Portlaoise and Clonmel, including the swimming pools, ring roads, shopping centres and whatever.
I agree with the Deputy that Leixlip needs a swimming pool and the-----
It needs a bridge and a road. Mr. Doheny said we do not have enough zoned land. Is there enough zoned land in Kildare?
I referred to zoned serviced land.
Yes.
In Kildare, we have the zoned land; if we can get it serviced, we-----
Exactly. It is a different issue. There is zoned land but we do not have the services. The places being discussed, like Tullamore-----
That is where the co-ordination aspect comes in.
That seems to be a big issue for the witnesses.

It is key to all of this. We could pick any place, and Nenagh is a good example. There may be reluctance at the moment to zone additional land because there are issues with the wastewater treatment in the town. Uisce Éireann recently announced that an upgrade to the wastewater treatment plant is scheduled to happen within the town. That is due to go to construction. Then there is the Shannon pipeline, which is due to go past the town, and the pipe extension that is due to go from the main pipeline into the town as part of phase 2. Should that be part of phase 1 to tie in with the wastewater treatment upgrade to ensure everything is co-ordinated together? These are the kinds of missing links in all of this. It is easy to zone land but if we do not have services, there is a problem. In some areas, services are being brought in but the land is not being zoned. Tying all that together will unlock land.
I thank the witnesses. I really appreciate their engagement.

The discussion has developed into a chat as opposed to anything else at this stage. I am delighted they have noticed there is an urgency within Government to provide housing and the infrastructure that goes with it. Irish Water seems to be doing what needs to be done to get to where we need to be to be able to build the houses, and the same with the ESB, EirGrid, etc. I spoke earlier about what the Government can do to cut costs out of building houses. Somebody mentioned reducing the number of consultants. Somebody else mentioned reducing VAT. How can we be sure, if we do all of that, that the witnesses' members will not just keep charging the same price to people who want to get on the property ladder? The history is that as grants increased in the past, the price of houses increased by nearly the same amount the next week. How can we be sure that if we do that work, the witnesses' members will not look for increased profits?
First, because the apartments are-----

I am not talking about apartments; I am talking about houses. We were talking earlier about houses and I asked how we can reduce their price. Houses are more expensive in Ireland than across in Europe. What is wrong with us? Mr. Doheny said two consultants were needed to build a scheme 20 years ago and now ten are needed. There is a cost attached to that. Somebody else mentioned that reducing VAT on apartments would make it more viable to build them. Reducing the VAT on houses, likewise, would make them cheaper. How can we be sure, if we do something like that, that the witnesses' members will not keep the price of houses the same, such that there is no advantage to the end customer?

As we outlined earlier in regard to finance, the pricing structure for housing is determined by an awful lot of factors outside our control. At the moment, we have a situation where we cannot build enough homes, and there are many different factors in that. Any builder would like to be building more at the moment. A huge cohort of the potential market is locked out at this time. Why would we build more homes and lock out that potentially huge market that is not being tapped into? "Tapped into" is the wrong phrase; I refer to the cohort that is not buying homes at the moment.

We also must look at the other price control mechanisms that are in place at the moment. Any builder in the Dublin region will say that going above €500,000 in relation to the help to buy scheme brings a completely different market. Any builder will say that at different regional locations, going above the price caps under the first home scheme means the market utterly changes. Those price caps are determined by looking at the average sale prices of new homes and what it takes to build within that environment. It is a lot different from times in the past when there was a completely different funding mechanism, a different market and a different banking system in place. We also now have the macro potential rules, which is another mechanism. I will not say they controls the price, but they certainly put on the brakes in regard to what the banks can lend to people in terms of their income and the income thresholds. All of those factors combined mean the builder's ability to determine whatever price he wants is gone.

Another point is that if more land is zoned and more competition is introduced into the marketplace, it will have an effect. Affordability is a big issue at the moment, so there already is a cohort of people who cannot afford to buy houses. Any sort of initiative that helps to reduce the price of houses would bring that cohort within the affordability range. Straight away, a new market is offered to the builder. Building is an industry with a production line. All builders want to do is produce and sell houses. They cannot afford to sit on the land or produce houses and not sell them. A good example is Moate, County Westmeath, where 20 affordable houses were recently brought onto the market, for which 180 people applied. Those 180 people cannot afford to pay the market price for those houses but they can afford to buy under the affordable incentive. Any incentive the Government might introduce to reduce the price of houses would bring more people into the market and would increase competition in the industry.
Is Mr. Doheny saying the best route to go would be to have more Government schemes for affordable housing to look after that cohort?

No, but if more zoned land is introduced and the numbers grow - say, increasing the load from 30,000 to 40,000 - more product would be brought onto the market. For any incentives to be competitive, the builder will have to bring those incentives to the bottom-line price for the houses.
On that point, before the famous crash, the more houses we built, the more house prices went up. The correlation was exactly not what one would expect it to be.
With all due respect-----
It got to the stage that people saw more houses and everyone had to have one. I would like that conundrum explained.

That happened at a particular time when the macro protection rules were not in place in the banking sector and we did not have the first home scheme or the help to buy scheme with thresholds in terms of what people could afford and avail of. It was a completely different environment.
Why did prices go up when supply went up?
The limit under the help to buy scheme in Offaly is €375,000, yet there are no three-bedroom semi-detached houses to be bought for that price under any scheme. They are all above that, at €400,000.

I am one of the oldest fellows in the room and I was in the eye of the storm when all of that was going on. The increase in the price of houses was more or less a function of interest rates and the fact money was so freely available. Everybody who was anybody - the postman and everyone else - was buying two or three houses. That created a false economy and the increased prices. We do not have that today. Money is not flying around like it was in those days.
We no longer have 120% mortgages.
Some mortgages were higher and included the cost of the wedding and the new car. Let us not go there again. Those were different times and they should not be revisited.

We have concluded our work for today. I thank the witnesses for assisting the committee. We might address one or two points to them through the secretariat that we did not get to address specifically today. They might get back to us with their thoughts on them within the next fortnight. Their information and insight is very important. Some of it was discussed yesterday. The nature of this committee is that we are cross-cutting every Department where infrastructure is relevant, be it housing, electricity, energy or whatever.

That is a good thing in its own right because until now everybody was in their own silo and it is no harm that some committee can see across all the different committees. We will cover similar ground and issues.

We hope the Government will soon have a report from its infrastructure task force. When that comes out it will be helpful and will set a framework for the future. The revised national development plan that came out earlier in the year did not have specific details, whereas the earlier plan had a lot of detail. In the weeks ahead, we are expecting to get specifics and a list of projects. The Department now knows its allocation under the national development plan from here to 2030, or thereafter. It knows how many of the ten projects it can fit in and it will prioritise some of those. People will see a pipeline as a result. That is expected in the coming weeks as well. It will be important information to give confidence in order that people will invest and make a long-term commitment to the industry.
We have covered the ground at this stage. I thank everyone.

debateSection.summary: The joint committee adjourned at 5.41 p.m. until 3.30 p.m. on Wednesday, 12 November 2025.
